Stem: A large hospital reviews its records and finds that patients who received a new, expensive heart medication have worse survival rates than those who received the old, standard medication. Assuming the new medication is at least as good as the old one, what’s the most plausible reason for this fact?

ScenarioDefinition.A_text: receiving the new, expensive heart medication
ScenarioDefinition.Intervention_Group: Patients receiving new, expensive heart medication
ScenarioDefinition.Observed_Outcome: Intervention group has worse survival rates
ScenarioDefinition.Constraint: The new medication is at least as good as the old one.

ThemeRegistry.description: The new medication was preferentially prescribed to patients with more severe illness or a worse baseline prognosis (Confounding by Indication).
The new medication was used as a 'last resort' for patients who were already deteriorating or had failed the standard treatment.
Patients receiving the new drug had more comorbidities (other health issues) or were generally frailer, which independently caused worse outcomes.
